thread.title: Last-second field goal sends No. 1 Coastal Carolina past Monmouth
thread.title_full: Last-second field goal sends No. 1 Coastal Carolina past Monmouth

author: app.com
title: Last-second field goal sends No. 1 Coastal Carolina past Monmouth
text:
MORE WEST LONG BRANCH -- Rarely, if ever, has the Monmouth University football team had so much anticipation surrounding it as it did Saturday when it hosted No. 1-ranked Coastal Carolina for Homecoming.
Homecoming always draws a crowd to Kessler, and the high-level opponent certainly didn't hurt, but the fact the Hawks stunned then-No. 22 Liberty last weekend got the hype machine churning last week for a top-ranked program's first-ever trip to West Long Branch.
Monmouth had its chances over four quarters, but in a game that seemed destined to be decided by who had the ball last, the Chanticleers executed late.
A Ryan Granger 30-yard field goal as time expired capped the scoring and ended a 12-play, 44-yard final drive as the Chanticleers survived Monmouth, 23-20, in front of a standing-room only crowd of 4,591 at Kessler.
"Losing a game is an opportunity lost because we could have put ourselves in good position in the conference, and been in good position in the conference race, in the thick of it," Monmouth head coach Kevin Callahan said.
Monmouth junior running back Lavon Chaney finished with a career-high 196 yards and two touchdowns, but was hampered in the fourth quarter by an ankle injury. Cody Williams finished 18-for-30 for 207 yards, one touchdown and one interception, while junior slot receiver Darren Ambush had a big day, catching nine Williams passes for 107 yards.
Coastal Carolina redshirt senior quarterback Alex Ross was solid, going 20-for-31 for 282 yards. All-American running back De'Angelo Henderson finished with 91 yards and a touchdown on 25 carries.
Ross, the reigning Big South Offensive Player of the Year, converted two third downs on the final drive to move the offense into position for Granger's field goal. A 17-yard pass over the middle on third-and-11 from the Monmouth 44-yard line moved the chains, as did a 12-yard pass to Tyrell Blanks on third-and-4 from the 21. The Chanticleers then handed off to Henderson three times before turning the game over to Granger.
The game-winning drive began with 3:02 left to play after Monmouth failed to convert on fourth-and-3 from the Coastal 43-yard line as Williams' pass to freshman wide receiver Ugo Ezemma fell incomplete.
"We all played well, we had our keys, we did our assignments, we practiced all week really hard to face a really quarterback and I think we held our own," senior cornerback Joe Johnson said. "I think we've proven over the last two weeks that we can play with almost anybody if we put our minds to it. I think we finally picked up enough steam where we have the confidence on defense that we're to go out and get the ball back to our offense. For the most part, we were able to do that today.
Granger's second field goal of the day, this one from 32 yards, gave Coastal Carolina a 20-13 lead with 3:30 to go in the third quarter, but Monmouth had an answer.
On the sixth play of the next drive, Chaney took a handoff, went left, broke a tackle, weaved his way through some traffic, then raced 21 yards for a touchdown. Matt White's extra point tied the game at 20 with 24 seconds to play in the third quarter.
